quiz.question: What happens to the position of equilibrium, if a reversible exothermic reaction is subjected to a decrease in temperature?

options.A: The position of equilibrium shifts to the left
options.B: The position of equilibrium shifts to the right.
options.C: The position of equilibrium remains unchanged

quiz.question: Which noble gas is radioactive and is produced as a decay product of uranium and thorium?
Which of the following reactions would be expected to have the highest entropy change?
What is the sum of the oxidation numbers in a neutral compound?
According to the kinetic theory of gases, the pressure exerted by a gas is due to

options.B: The weight of the gas particles
options.C: The attractive forces between gas particles
options.D: The collisions of gas particles with the container walls

quiz.question: What is eutrophication?

options.A: The release of harmful chemicals into water bodies
options.B: The excessive growth of algae due to nutrient enrichment
options.C: The presence of heavy metals in water
options.D: The formation of oil slicks on water surfaces

quiz.question: What is the name of the process by which ammonia is produced on an industrial scale?
Who proposed the planetary model of the atom with electrons orbiting the nucleus?
Which of the following is an example of an endothermic reaction?

options.A: Combustion of propane (C3H8) to produce carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O).
options.B: Burning of methane (CH4) in the presence of oxygen
options.C: Formation of table salt (NaCl) from sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl2).
options.D: Decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) into water (H2O) and oxygen (O2).

quiz.question: What happens to the value of the equilibrium constant (Kc) for a reaction if the reaction is reversed?

options.D: It becomes the reciprocal of the original value

quiz.question: What is the chemical structure of soap and detergent molecules?
What is the solubility product constant (Ksp) used for?

options.A: To measure the total mass of a solute that can dissolve in a solvent
options.B: To determine the concentration of a solute in a saturated solution
options.C: To calculate the solubility of a solute in a given solvent
options.D: To compare the solubilities of different solutes in the same solvent

quiz.question: Which trace gas in the atmosphere plays a significant role in the greenhouse effect?
Which of the following methods can be used to remove temporary hardness from water?
What is Faraday's constant?
A gas occupies a volume of 1.5 liters at a pressure of 2 atmospheres. If the pressure is increased to 4 atmospheres while the temperature remains constant, what will be the new volume of the gas?
Stainless steel is an alloy made up of
What is the state of matter in which particles are widely spaced and move freely with high kinetic energy?
Identify the reducing agent in the following reaction: Zn + CuSO4 → ZnSO4 + Cu
Balance the following redox reaction: Fe2O3 + CO → Fe + CO2
What is the trend for ionization energy across a period in the periodic table?
Which type of chemical combination involves the transfer of electrons from one atom to another, resulting in the formation of oppositely charged ions?
Which of the following alkanes has a straight-chain structure?
What is the product of the electrolysis of aqueous sodium chloride (NaCl) using inert electrodes?

options.A: Hydrogen gas at the cathode and chlorine gas at the anode
options.B: Hydrogen gas at the cathode and oxygen gas at the anode
options.C: Sodium metal at the cathode and chlorine gas at the anode
options.D: Sodium metal at the cathode and oxygen gas at the anode

quiz.question: When an acidic solution is diluted, what happens to its pH?

options.A: It depends on the specific acid

quiz.question: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the rate of a chemical reaction?
Which organic compound is responsible for the characteristic aroma of fruits?
What is the molar mass of water (H2O)?
What is the chemical formula of rust, which is formed on the surface of iron in the presence of oxygen and moisture?
How many pi (π) bonds are there in an alkene with six carbon atoms?
What is the principal ore of iron, from which iron is extracted?
Which group does calcium belong to in the periodic table?
Which of the following is a primary constituent of crude oil?
What is the main source of carbon monoxide (CO) in urban areas?
What is the empirical formula of a compound containing 40.00% carbon, 6.67% hydrogen, and 53.33% oxygen by mass?
Which separation technique is used to separate different pigments in a mixture based on their affinity for a stationary phase and a mobile phase?
What is the common name for ethanoic acid?
What type of reaction is involved in the formation of alkanols from alkenes?
What is the mass percentage of carbon (C) in methane (CH4)? (The molar mass of carbon is approximately 12 g/mol.)
Which of the following is a common property of non-metals?

options.A: Exist as solids at room temperature
options.B: Tend to gain electrons in chemical reactions
options.D: Readily form cations in chemical reactions
